CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security
JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Elisabet Fura;Ineta Ziemele;Josep Casadevall
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in Ploieşti .
CARDINAL . The LOC police started an investigation into allegations that the applicant had stolen petroleum products from his employer , an oil company .
CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant was apprehended by the police .
On DATE the prosecutor attached to ORG issued an arrest warrant against the applicant for DATE , until DATE . The prosecutor ’s order gave the following reasons for seeking the applicant ’s arrest :
“ the offence is punishable by DATE detention , and [ the applicant ’s ] continued liberty represents a threat to ordre public . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was brought before ORG in order to have the lawfulness of his committal for trial and of his pre - trial detention verified . The applicant ’s lawyer requested that the detention order be set aside and the applicant released , arguing , in particular , that the arrest warrant was unlawful and that the measure of placing the applicant in pretrial detention had been taken automatically and too easily , as there was no evidence that he had committed the offence in question .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , considering that the reasons justifying the initial measure remained unchanged , ordered the applicant ’s detention in custody for DATE , namely until QUANTITY DATE . It noted that its decision was subject to appeal at the same time as the judgment on the merits of the case .

CARDINAL . CARDINAL more hearings took place before ORG . Each time the applicant ’s pre - trial detention was extended for similar reasons to those of DATE , until the judgment on the merits was delivered . No further grounds were given by ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG convicted the applicant of aggravated theft and imposed a DATE suspended sentence .
CARDINAL . The applicant was released from custody on DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG dismissed an appeal lodged by the applicant and upheld ORG judgment in a final decision of DATE .
CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on DATE , the applicant was dismissed from his job in application of LAW , as his detention had exceeded DATE . He found a new job on DATE .

CARDINAL . The procedure for lodging complaints against preventive measures , including pre - trial detention , is described in DATE Code of Criminal Procedure ( see PERSON v. GPE DATE . ) , no . CARDINAL , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , only the decision whereby the court takes , sets aside , replaces or ends a preventive measure can be appealed against independently from the judgment on the merits of the case , and this must be done within DATE of the date of the interlocutory judgment .
CARDINAL . Persons who have been unlawfully detained can avail themselves of CARDINAL actions for damages described in LAW and in the Civil Code respectively .
CARDINAL . The relevant LAW provides :

“ Anyone who has been convicted by a final decision is entitled to compensation from the ORG for any loss or damage sustained where , after a retrial , it is held in a judgment against which no appeal lies that he did not commit the offence in question or that no offence was committed .

Anyone against whom a preventive measure has been taken , and in whose favour a decision to discontinue proceedings or acquit has been given for the reasons listed in the preceding paragraph , also enjoys a right to compensation for damage sustained ... ”

CARDINAL . In a decision of CARDINAL DATE , published on DATE in ORG , ORG , to which an objection had been submitted alleging that the first paragraph of LAW was unconstitutional , ruled as follows :

“ Under LAW , the ORG is liable for damage caused by miscarriages of justice committed in criminal proceedings . It follows that the principle of the ORG ’s liability towards victims of a miscarriage of justice in a criminal trial must be applied to all victims of such a miscarriage . ... The ORG notes that the legislature has not brought the provisions of LAW into conformity with those of LAW . ... Consequently , bearing in mind that LAW provides for CARDINAL cases in which the ORG ’s responsibility for miscarriages of justice committed in criminal proceedings may be engaged , it follows that this restriction is unconstitutional , since LAW does not allow for any such limitation . ”
LAW has been modified by PERSON no . CARDINAL . Its new version reflects ORG decision above .
CARDINAL . The relevant Articles of the Civil Code provide :
“ Anyone who , through his own fault , causes damage to another shall be liable to make reparation for it . ”
“ Anyone who causes damage as a result of his own action , his failure to act or his negligence shall be liable for that damage . ”
